race.name: Montana Gravel Challenge
race.tagline: Montana Gravel Challenge. 65 miles of gravel through Huson.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Montana mountains. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional MT event. Mountain terrain with remote location, high altitude, and small regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Montana Gravel Challenge is a regional event in Montana‚Äîmountain terrain with significant elevation and high altitude. The Montana mountains are scenic, but the small regional field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional MT mountain gravel race. Worth it for MT/Mountain West riders. Not worth traveling far for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to MT‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're traveling‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better MT races: Big Sky Gravel, Dusty Bandita.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Huson has limited lodging. Stay in Missoula.
logistics.food: Huson has limited dining. Stock nutrition or eat in Missoula.
logistics.camping: onsite camping/trailer camping at the race HQ (18450 Six Mile Road, Huson, MT)

course_description.signature_challenge: Montana mountains terrain at high altitude.
course_description.ridewithgps_name: 2023 Montana Gravel Challenge : Southside Road Stage 2 Saturday

non_negotiables.why: Montana mountains require sustained mountain effort.
Limited aid stations and remote location require self-sufficiency.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with mountain terrain and high altitude.

logistics.explanation: The race operates from Big Sky Brewery owner Bjorn's private property with onsite camping and bike wash stations. Peter L notes "The guy who hosts the race had bike wash stations in his yard so after every stage I hosed off my bike." Registration happens on-site each morning with coffee and treats, though poor cell connectivity delays results posting until end of day.

length.explanation: The three-stage format totals around 110 miles over the weekend - 11-mile Friday TT, 56-mile Saturday road stage, and 45-mile Sunday circuit race. Peter L's power data shows the TT takes ~20 minutes while Saturday requires 2+ hours of sustained effort. The format allows single-stage entries for riders not wanting the full omnium commitment. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Only the Friday TT runs 100% gravel, while Saturday and Sunday stages mix significant pavement with gravel sections. Peter L describes course modifications due to conditions: "definitely good call to avoid the twisty descent that was already pretty fucked before it rained more." Technical challenge comes from variable surfaces and weather-dependent routing rather than sustained gravel difficulty. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: Saturday packs 3,000 feet into 56 miles while other stages stay moderate - 756 feet Friday, 1,711 feet Sunday. Peter L notes the TT "is rolling and uphill finish so having something left for that is good." Sunday's circuit includes "about 2k generally uphill to the finish" after each lap's climb and descent. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Late April timing delivers unpredictable conditions. Peter L experienced the 2024 reality: "This weekend was the 3-day montana gravel challenge, and it's raining." He dressed "for cold and rain which was forecast but didn't really happen," then faced muddy sections that "has only gotten worse over the last few days of periodic rain and cool temps." More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Huson sits around 3,000-4,000 feet elevation in the Missoula valley. Peter L's power numbers (338w average, 361w normalized for the TT) suggest the altitude impact is manageable for most riders. The elevation affects pacing more through the rolling terrain profile than thin air, based on his race experience data. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: Course routing adapts to conditions, with organizers shortening the TT and skipping dangerous gravel sections when weather deteriorates. Peter L describes Sunday's mud climb as "a section I cut out of the TT on friday morning because it was a little iffy." The three-day format across Montana's variable spring conditions creates unpredictable challenges.

prestige.explanation: This remains a regional Montana event with no notable pro participation or prize purse. Peter L's race report focuses on local age group competition, noting "Matt beat me to win 40+" and racing alongside local riders like Porter and Brian. The Cycling House and Competitive Timing provide professional organization but not national-level competition.

race_quality.explanation: Saturday runs 68% pavement (38 of 56 miles) and Sunday 60% pavement (27 of 45 miles), making this more mixed-surface than pure gravel. Peter L calls Sunday the "road race" stage. Professional timing by Competitive Timing and proper course marking provide solid race infrastructure, but the surface breakdown doesn't match typical gravel race expectations.

experience.explanation: Multi-day format creates cumulative fatigue challenges. Peter L tracked his recovery: "yesterday morning I felt like garbage and my watch told me my 'training readiness' was 14. This morning it said 7 but I felt better." Weather variability and course changes keep riders adapting, though significant pavement mileage dilutes the pure gravel experience most seek.

community.explanation: Race headquarters at Bjorn's brewery property with onsite camping creates a festival atmosphere. Peter L notes team tactics working on Sunday's circuit: "We had a good team of like 5 of us, with Ivan's dad, Porter, Brian, and myself." All three-stage finishers receive Montana Gravel Challenge hats, and daily podiums maintain engagement throughout the weekend.

field_depth.explanation: Recreation and paracyclist divisions suggest limited competitive depth, with virtual participation options further indicating registration challenges. Peter L's race reports focus on small group tactics and local age group battles rather than deep fields. The $40-150 price range and same-day registration availability point to accessibility over exclusivity. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Peter L puts it: "Day 2 has been the long gravel stage of the race with 3 being a more road circuit."

value.explanation: Three days for $150 includes onsite camping, bike wash stations, daily registration with coffee and treats, and finisher hats. Peter L appreciated the venue amenities: "The guy who hosts the race had bike wash stations in his yard so after every stage I hosed off my bike." Individual stage options ($40-110) provide flexibility without forcing full weekend commitment.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $80-100. Recommended lodging at City Center Motel in Missoula keeps costs reasonable, with free onsite camping as an alternative. Peter L ran 34mm tires at 42-46 psi on his Orbea Terra with road wheels, noting "The bike, wheel, and tire setup was perfect all weekend." Late April timing avoids peak Montana tourism pricing while maintaining access to Missoula's amenities. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: I Tried SUPER Wide Tyres On My Gravel Bike But There Was 1 BIG Problem
videos.description:
Running super wide or mtb tyres on a gravel bike seems to be one of the best upgrades you can make to a gravel bike in 2025 so we thought we'd copy the gravel racing pros and see if mountain bike tyres on a gravel bike actually makes it better...

In the video Jamie tries out 2.2" (55mm) mtb tyres on his gravel bike - a Lauf Seigla to decide whether they're better than his usual 45mm gravel tyres. Which are the best gravel bike tyres and what are the best width gravel bike tyres? Jamie from Cycling Weekly thinks a 50mm tyre is perfect for most gravel cycling here in the UK.

Let us know what size gravel bike tyres and the best gravel bike upgrades you've made in the comments below...

We may earn a commission when purchasing through affiliate links in this description.

Subscribe to Cycling Weekly here: https://www.youtube.com/user/CyclingWeekly1?sub_confirmation=1

More at:
Cycling Weekly: http://www.cyclingweekly.com
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/CyclingWeekly
Instagram: https://instagram.com/cyclingweeklymagazine
Twitter: http://twitter.com/cyclingweekly
Email: cycling@futurenet.com

#cycling #bikes #bicycles

quite easy, doesn't it? Now, I do think
that bike manufacturers are going to
have to listen to consumers and the
science and start making their
clearances a lot wider. And they have,
to be fair, a lot of even the race
bikes, race gravel bikes that we've seen
released this year have got those wider
clearances. That Villia Rave ID2 springs
to mind. Now, I say that fit as wide a
tire as possible. And then I'm actually
going to contradict myself almost
immediately because what I now want to
do to this bike is move down to a 50 mil
tire. So these are 55 mil, 2.2 in. I
think a 2.1 in or 50 mil is going to be
the sweet spot for my riding and this
bike. And I'm hoping I'm making that
decision because I'm hoping that it will
eliminate that toe overlap that you saw
I got earlier. Therefore, hopefully I
can have all the benefits of big tires
without any of the negatives. In
conclusion, then, wide gravel tires have
done enough to convince me that they are
a genuine option rather than just a
gimmick. Let me know whether you agree
or disagree with my tire choice down in
the comments below, as well as any
questions that you'd like us to answer
on the channel next. We'll see you next

videos.title: Gravel Racing is HARD! (Full Race Breakdown - Belgian Waffle Ride Utah)
videos.description:
This is the full race recap of my effort at the belgian waffle ride in Cedar City Utah. I walk you through the whole race, breakdown each sector, and give you my cycling commentary as the gravel race plays out.   

The belgian waffle ride has a mission to be known as the hardest one day bike races in North America, and this gravel race in Cedar City, Utah lives up to that goal. This gravel race had one of the best courses ive ever ridden. It wasn't too difficult so if you had good base fitness and bike handling skills, you felt pretty competitive for a while. 

BIKE SETUP : 
Bike - Canyon Grail
Wheels - IRC double cross 38s on Princeton carbonworks rims
Gearing - 2x 50/34 - 11/40
Road Shoes and pedals 

NUTRITION: 
(What I started with)
x2 cups of coffee
600 calories in SIS gels
900 calories in bottles
x2 30g bottles of ketones (should be illegal)  
(What I got on the road)
2 waters
4 SIS gels
1 Cliff Block

STRAVA
https://www.strava.com/activities/4208272197/analysis

Check out Dylan and his top 5 finish here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ri8mtN5O-0o

DAILY VLOG VIDEOS: 
Day 1 - https://youtu.be/4SYlO9PmVNs
Day 2 - https://youtu.be/f_8AO3wAGIQ

videos.title: Crazy Hard 50-Mile Gravel Bike Race with 5000' of climbing! Prattsburgh, NY
videos.description:
üé•NY's Largest Gravel Bike Race - Black Fly Challenge https://youtu.be/h7HeUxWifs4

Gravel Bike Race the Keuka Gravel Race 50 miles, 5,000 feet route course. With 20% + Hill Climb Elevation Grades! 50mph gravel bike downhills on gravel bike aero bars or TT bars. Gravel racing at its best! The Keuka Lake Gravel Classic starts & ends at Steuben Brewing Company. Gravel cycling in Western NY Finger Lakes region. 

Strava Ride Log - https://www.strava.com/activities/7186655238

Mixer of paved, dirt, rocks, stone roads with several sectors of ‚Äúseasonal use roads‚Äù.  These sectors make for some of the most exciting sections of the race as they offer the most difficult and thrilling terrain.

The aero clip on bars are a huge help to gain speed. Aerodynamics from head winds are reduced with aerobars. 

From the creator of the Durty Bikes Gravel Series & born from the Ramble around Prattsburgh NY that began in 2008.

Curtis J White is a professional cyclocross racer who competes across the US and Europe against the world‚Äôs best riders took the overall win!

Race Results
https://steubenbrewingcompany.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/2022-KLGC-Results.pdf

Keuka Lake Gravel Classic 50 - Course Map
https://www.strava.com/clubs/575738/group_events/1094226

~For more pictures and reels head to Instagram~ 
 https://www.instagram.com/4_season_cycling/
